issue.title: Atlas v3 URDF has no collision models

content.raw: Can you clarify this? The [atlas_v3.urdf](#!/osrf/drcsim/src/710854ec0d72a28292700afea3185181eb9c9f2e/atlas_description/urdf/atlas_v3.urdf?at=default#cl-17) model has mesh collision elements that match the visuals. Am I missing something?
content.html: Can you clarify this? The atlas_v3.urdf model has mesh collision elements that match the visuals. Am I missing something?

issue.title: Atlas v3 URDF has no collision models

content.raw: Run RVIZ and try to look at the Robot Model.  Legs are missing.  Then try looking at collision models, only the multisense shows a collision model.  The self_filter packages in ROS also complain when trying to load collisions for links from this URDF, but are perfectly happy with the older URDF.
content.html: Run RVIZ and try to look at the Robot Model. Legs are missing. Then try looking at collision models, only the multisense shows a collision model. The self_filter packages in ROS also complain when trying to load collisions for links from this URDF, but are perfectly happy with the older URDF.

content.html: Duplicate of #360.

issue.title: Atlas v3 URDF has no collision models

content.raw: Try pull request #384
content.html: Try pull request #384

issue.title: Atlas v3 URDF has no collision models

content.raw:
This is NOT an exact duplicate.  While those new DAE files look correct in rviz now, they still do not work with long standing ROS code that uses such files, so still must not be fully correct.

geometric_shapes ROS package has a shape_operations class that has a createMeshFromFilename() function that takes in a collada file and uses the creates a mesh.  This is stuff used by the robot_self_filter and other packages.  createMeshFromFilename() worked on the v2 URDF models, but these v3 models cause that function to fail, so somthing is still wrong with them.
content.html:
This is NOT an exact duplicate. While those new DAE files look correct in rviz now, they still do not work with long standing ROS code that uses such files, so still must not be fully correct.

geometric_shapes ROS package has a shape_operations class that has a createMeshFromFilename() function that takes in a collada file and uses the creates a mesh. This is stuff used by the robot_self_filter and other packages. createMeshFromFilename() worked on the v2 URDF models, but these v3 models cause that function to fail, so somthing is still wrong with them.

issue.title: Atlas v3 URDF has no collision models

content.raw: I think perhaps the models might be correct, but the way that geometric_shapes packages opens files is messed up.  Closing agian.
content.html: I think perhaps the models might be correct, but the way that geometric_shapes packages opens files is messed up. Closing agian.

issue.title: Atlas v3 URDF has no collision models

content.raw:
Are you guys dropping all support for fuerte, or will you be fixing the drcsim 3.0 model so it works in simulation?  Should we switch to groovy/hydro?  Which would be best?

Right now we've got the this issue as well as the ankles being unstable (ie, any damping makes it go unstable, as does raising a leg then setting it down).
content.html:
Are you guys dropping all support for fuerte, or will you be fixing the drcsim 3.0 model so it works in simulation? Should we switch to groovy/hydro? Which would be best?

Right now we've got the this issue as well as the ankles being unstable (ie, any damping makes it go unstable, as does raising a leg then setting it down).

issue.title: Atlas v3 URDF has no collision models

content.raw: We are using Fuerte.  We are using the debian packages for drcsim, which are for fuerte.  You OSRF guys need to realize that teams have many members that use their own laptops, home machines, work machines, etc.  We can't all be building drcsim from source for every new branch or pull request against groovy, hydro whatever, so if you are going to put out Debian packages that build against Fuerte, which I recommend highly you continue to do, then you need to use models that are supported by the tools in Fuerte.  The current DAE files have some issue that does not allow the Fuerte geometric_shapes package to load the meshes.  Thus no planning, no self filtering from perception, no self collision detection, etc.
content.html: We are using Fuerte. We are using the debian packages for drcsim, which are for fuerte. You OSRF guys need to realize that teams have many members that use their own laptops, home machines, work machines, etc. We can't all be building drcsim from source for every new branch or pull request against groovy, hydro whatever, so if you are going to put out Debian packages that build against Fuerte, which I recommend highly you continue to do, then you need to use models that are supported by the tools in Fuerte. The current DAE files have some issue that does not allow the Fuerte geometric_shapes package to load the meshes. Thus no planning, no self filtering from perception, no self collision detection, etc.

issue.title: Atlas v3 URDF has no collision models

content.raw: I am not familiar with `geometric_shapes` package, could it be that  `geometric_shapes` library works with STL's but not DAE's?  If that's the case, we could generate corresponding STL for each mesh for the new Atlas model for now?
content.html: I am not familiar with geometric_shapes package, could it be that geometric_shapes library works with STL's but not DAE's? If that's the case, we could generate corresponding STL for each mesh for the new Atlas model for now?

issue.title: Atlas v3 URDF has no collision models

content.raw: It's unclear whether createMeshFromFile is for STL or DAE.  The documentation is too sparse.  But it shoudl be easy to just run createMeshFromFilename("package://atlas_v3/....DAE") in a simple standalone program to test this.  I considered doing this, but then I run into the problem of needing to create new STL files each time drcsim updates with changed DAE files, and make sure everyone checks these out and uses them.  I think it would be very helpful if you guys could supply STL files, if this works.  I would be willing to try this on Thursday if you sent an STL file (I guess I could generate one from MeshLab myself and try this tomorrow).  But again, this is trivial to set up and test in a 1 line main().
content.html: It's unclear whether createMeshFromFile is for STL or DAE. The documentation is too sparse. But it shoudl be easy to just run createMeshFromFilename("package://atlas_v3/....DAE") in a simple standalone program to test this. I considered doing this, but then I run into the problem of needing to create new STL files each time drcsim updates with changed DAE files, and make sure everyone checks these out and uses them. I think it would be very helpful if you guys could supply STL files, if this works. I would be willing to try this on Thursday if you sent an STL file (I guess I could generate one from MeshLab myself and try this tomorrow). But again, this is trivial to set up and test in a 1 line main().

issue.title: Atlas v3 URDF has no collision models

content.raw:
It's called in the robot_self_filter package and arm_navigation stack 
when planning.  That's about all I can say, other than you can probably 
just make a simple program that calls that one function and see if you 
get the same warning that I posted above.  In any case, it should be 
obvious by about 10 AM CST tomorrow if this fixes the problem.
content.html: It's called in the robot_self_filter package and arm_navigation stack when planning. That's about all I can say, other than you can probably just make a simple program that calls that one function and see if you get the same warning that I posted above. In any case, it should be obvious by about 10 AM CST tomorrow if this fixes the problem.

issue.title: Atlas v3 URDF has no collision models

content.raw:
Only using the STL for collision doesn't stop the rviz segfaults. 
Soemthign in OGRE doesn't like the STL files.

So we have Fuerte geometry tool  that hate the collada, and Fuerte OGRE 
tools that hate the STL.

Looks like John used Meshlab to do the DAE-->STL conversion. Maybe I can 
find time at some point to look into a different converter, which may 
fix this.
content.html:
Only using the STL for collision doesn't stop the rviz segfaults. Soemthign in OGRE doesn't like the STL files.

So we have Fuerte geometry tool that hate the collada, and Fuerte OGRE tools that hate the STL.

Looks like John used Meshlab to do the DAE-->STL conversion. Maybe I can find time at some point to look into a different converter, which may fix this.

issue.title: Atlas v3 URDF has no collision models

content.html:
@patrickbeeson

I've found the culprit to rviz segfault in fuerte. The stl files that I resized manually with ivcon tool were ascii files. I've pushed in a fix so collisions load correctly in fuerte.

Visuals in fuerte are still scaled incorrectly though (see my attachment rviz_fuerte.png, where textured meshes are visuals, and red colored meshes are collision meshes).
